channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Miklos Jancso, Who Directed Stylized Films of War and Tyranny in Hungary, Dies at 92
item.description: Mr. Jancso built an international reputation with a handful of early works, including “The Round-Up” and “Red Psalm,” that were distinct in both style and substance.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER

item.title: His Friends Know Him as Petroswickonicovick
item.description: Carrying an extraordinary name is remarkably widespread in Brazil. Just ask Wonarllevyston Garlan Marllon Branddon Bruno Paullynelly Mell Oliveira Pereira.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petroswickonicovick Wandeckerkof da Silva Santos has also turned heads as a soccer prodigy.

item.title: Spurred by Global Crises, Germany Weighs a More Muscular Foreign Policy
item.description: Some German leaders are even suggesting that the country should no longer reflexively avoid some military deployments, as it did in Libya almost three years ago.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Syrian Helicopters Drop Barrel Bombs on Aleppo
item.description: The bombs killed at least 23 people, including a family trapped in a burning car, activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Major Volcanic Eruption Kills at Least 14 in Indonesia
item.description: Mount Sinabung, which has been erupting for months, unleashed a major eruption on Saturday, a day after evacuated villagers were allowed to return home.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: In China, ‘Once the Villages Are Gone, the Culture Is Gone’
item.description: As village life in China disappears and its traditions fade, some fight to maintain the country’s rural cultural heritage.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arriving at Mount Miaofeng, on what used to be a great pilgrimage route, a girl dressed to perform at the temple there took a break from the trek uphill.

item.title: Political Candidate’s Aides Die in Afghanistan Attack
item.description: Two employees of Abdullah Abdullah, a presidential candidate, were fatally shot in the relatively secure city of Herat.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Two employees of Abdullah Abdullah, a presidential candidate, were killed Saturday.

item.title: Kerry and Hagel Defend U.S. Engagement Abroad in Face of Criticism
item.description: Speaking at the Munich Security Conference, Secretary of State John Kerry expressed some exasperation with the criticism that the United States was retreating from a leadership role.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: In Munich for a conference, Secretary of State John Kerry, second from right, met with Ukrainian opposition figures on Saturday.

item.title: Stunned by Tragedy, a Village in Rural Quebec Turns Inward
item.description: After a fire swept through a retirement home in L’Isle-Verte, killing dozens, Quebec is experiencing a horrible sense of déjà vu: it has been only seven months since an oil train exploded into a fireball in Lac-Mégantic, killing 47.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency personnel combed through the rubble of the Résidence Du Havre last Wednesday, searching for human remains.

item.title: Diver Killed Working on Concordia in Italy
item.description: A diver died Saturday while working on the shipwrecked Costa Concordia, apparently gashing his leg on an underwater metal sheet while preparing the wreck for removal, officials and news reports said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Indians Protest, Saying a Death Was Tied to Bias
item.description: Hundreds from India’s far northeast demonstrated outside a New Delhi police station, furious over the death of an 18-year-old and complaining of discrimination because of their East Asian features.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE and MAX BEARAK

item.title: Town Is Secured in Central Africa
item.description: African peacekeepers trying to stabilize the Central African Republic said they had regained control of a town where hundreds of heavily armed rebels had massed.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Protesters Beat Police Officer in Ukraine, Ministry Says
item.description: Antigovernment protesters in Kiev captured and beat a plainclothes policeman in the part of the city controlled by demonstrators, the authorities said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: 733 Iraqis Killed in January, U.N. Reports
item.description: At least 733 Iraqis, most of them civilians, were killed during violence in January, not including casualties from an embattled western province, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gun Battle in Bangkok Escalates Election Protest
item.description: At least six were injured in a battle between protesters seeking to block the distribution of ballots and would-be voters demanding that protesters stop trying to obstruct elections on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: An antigovernment protester with his pistol on Saturday during a clash in Bangkok with supporters of the government.

item.title: India Ink: Judge’s Family Denies Pride Was Behind Rejection of 3rd-Highest Award
item.description: The survivors of Jagdish Sharan Verma, who was instrumental in strengthening laws protecting women, said he wouldn’t have accepted any award had he been alive.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA

item.title: World Briefing: British Nuclear Reprocessing Plant Detected Elevated Radiation Levels
item.description: The high levels were caused by naturally occurring background radon, not by any faults at the aging plant, the operating company said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Bloomberg Picked to Be Climate Envoy
item.description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has a new job: United Nations special envoy for cities and climate change.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: 17 Soldiers Killed in Ambushes in Yemen
item.description: Gunmen attacked a checkpoint and a police patrol on Friday in eastern Yemen, killing 17 soldiers, military and security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Aid Groups Warn of Food Crisis in Mali
item.description: The agencies said Friday that more than 800,000 people in northern Mali needed immediate food aid and that three million people nationwide were at risk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israeli Military Strikes Targets in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said it struck a plant for weapons manufacturing, a weapons storage site and what it called a “terror activity site.”
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Violence in Central African Republic’s Capital Alarms Red Cross
item.description: Attacks in Bangui have reached “unprecedented levels” with at least 30 people killed in the past three days, humanitarian officials said.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Is Said to Plan Fence-Mending Trip to Saudi Arabia
item.description: An official said President Obama would seek to reassure King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia after a period of tension over American policies toward Iran and Syria.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: On 35th Anniversary of Diplomatic Ties With U.S., China Tries to Soften Image
item.description: China has moved to expand friendly cultural exchanges with the United States and promote a series of prominent collaborations in music, dance and education, particularly in New York.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man in Beijing turned away on Friday after setting off firecrackers to celebrate the start of the Chinese New Year.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Even Out of Office, a Wielder of Great Power in Yemen
item.description: Ali Abdullah Saleh, Yemen’s former president, is a rarity in the Arab world: an autocrat overthrown by popular revolt who nonetheless remains in his country, undisturbed.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:credit: Hani Mohammed/Associated Press, Photo from September 2012
item.media:description: “These people are not confident of their power, and still consider themselves as employees of Ali Abdullah Saleh,” Saleh said of his critics.
